p: Nevertheless, the availability of information alone remains unlikely to motivate adaptation (Cash et al. 2002; Patt & Schroter 2008). Individuals seek or receive, manage and interpret information in different ways and then use or reject it. Frank et al. ( 2010) argue that smallholder farmers’ knowledge is largely a synthesis derived from personal experience, local sources of knowledge and external sources of techno-scientific information. How farmers perceive scientists and their knowledge is likely to affect farmers’ use of scientific information in making decisions. Cash et al. (2002) argue that at the core of any decision process involving the creation of knowledge, individuals assess the salience, credibility and legitimacy of available information. Cash et al. ( 2003) propose that effective management of these three components of information is central to successful knowledge production and the ability to mobilise knowledge for desired actions.
